title: How to Wash Linen Sheets

steps.headline: Separate your sheets by color.
steps.description: Before you put your linen bedding through the wash, divvy it up into white, dark, and colored piles. Linen doesn’t hold dye as well as some fabrics, and you don’t want to risk running, bleeding, or color cross-over. Ideally, you should also wash linen separately from other fabrics that may snag or shed whenever possible.

steps.headline: Pre-treat stains with a mild stain remover or water prior to washing.
steps.description: Spray or dab small stains with an enzyme-based stain remover, or one made with natural ingredients like vinegar, lemon, or hydrogen peroxide. You also have the option of soaking heavily-stained sheets in cold water (warm water can cause stains to set permanently) for 10-20 minutes prior to washing. For a gentler touch, pass on the commercial stain removers and instead use a solution made from cold water and about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) mild liquid detergent. If you decide to use a commercial stain remover, check to make sure that it doesn't contain bleach or ammonia. Chemical oxidizers and natural fabrics are a bad mix.

steps.headline: Wash your sheets using cold or lukewarm water.
steps.description: As a rule, it’s best to stick with lower wash temperatures when laundering linen. While the fabric is exceptionally resilient in most ways, it is somewhat susceptible to heat damage, especially while it’s wet. Washing your bedding with cool or cold water will also help save you money on your utility bill. Win-win!

steps.headline: Set your washing machine to the gentle cycle.
steps.description: This will help ensure that your sheets don’t take too much of a beating. It doesn’t take much agitation to get ordinary amounts of dirt and oil out of linen. Rougher cycles will only subject your sheets to unnecessary wear and tear.

steps.headline: Leave a little room inside your washer while loading it.
steps.description: Overfilling your washing machine is an easy mistake to make, but it can cause your linen bedding to break down before its time. The more room there is inside the barrel, the cleaner your sheets will get, and the less they’ll rub against each other or lose their shape. Depending on the size of your washing machine, you may only be able to run a single set of sheets at a time. If you have enough dirty sheets to completely fill up your washer, it's a good idea to clean it in batches.

steps.headline: Use a mild or all-natural liquid detergent.
steps.description: Biodegradable detergents and those designed for delicate types of clothing are a good choice. The harsh chemicals found in regular and extra-strength detergents can gradually break down organic fabrics like linen. Stay away from powdered soaps and detergent. These can easily get trapped in the tightly-woven fabric, leading to inconsistent cleaning and more rapid deterioration.Tip: Look for detergents that use water and plant-based surfactants as their primary active ingredients.

steps.headline: Blot or soak stains to weaken their hold on the fabric.
steps.description: Use an enzyme-based stain remover to spot-treat small stains. For extensive staining, you can also try working a small amount of mild liquid detergent into the stain with your fingertips and giving the sheets a preliminary soak for 10-20 minutes. When soaking stains, squeeze the fabric around the stain periodically to help the soapy water penetrate the affected area. Sadly, there's no guarantee that you'll be able to erase every last trace of a heavy stain from white or light-colored sheets.

steps.headline: Fill a large container with cold or lukewarm water.
steps.description: Choose a container that’s big enough to comfortably hold all of the sheets you want to wash, with a little extra room left over. You want your sheets to be surrounded with lots of water in order to minimize friction and tangling, both of which can cause your bedding to wear out faster. Washing your clothes in a spacious sink can make setting and cleaning up a cinch, reducing your overall wash time.Tip: Buckets, rubber storage containers, and metal wash tubs are useful for hand washing large items like sheets if you don’t have a suitably-sized sink.

steps.headline: Add roughly 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of mild liquid detergent.
steps.description: Pour in the detergent, then stir the water gently by hand to mix it in. Taking a moment to dilute the detergent will ensure that it does its job without being any harder on your sheets than it needs to be. Be careful not to use too much detergent. Doing so is likely to damage your linens in the long run.

steps.headline: Swish your sheets through the soapy water gently.
steps.description: Plunge the sheets below the surface of the water with both hands and whisk them back and forth for a few seconds. Then, take hold of a different section and do the same thing. This kind of easy back-and-forth action will be more than enough to loosen any dirt and body oil that’s built up in the fabric. There’s no need to scrub, wring, or otherwise be forceful with your sheets. Manhandling them will only weaken the fibers of the linen.

steps.headline: Rinse your sheets thoroughly to remove all traces of detergent.
steps.description: Drain your washing container, refill it with clean water, and repeat the process, plunging and swishing your sheets in sections to flush any remaining suds out the fibers. Before taking them out, inspect them to make sure that they’re completely free of soapy residue. You may need to empty and refill your container a second time, depending on how much sheets you’re washing and how much detergent you used.

steps.headline: Squeeze the excess water out of your sheets.
steps.description: Fold the sheets up loosely and press them between your hands to coax out as much lingering moisture as possible. Don’t wring or twist them, as this can stretch the fibers beyond their natural range of motion and cause them to permanently lose their shape. Squeezing the water out of your sheets will cut down on the time it takes them to dry, whether you intend to dry them in a machine or on a line.

steps.headline: Tumble your sheets on a low heat setting to dry them quickly.
steps.description: Transfer your sheets to the dryer immediately after washing them and select the tumble dry or wrinkle release option. They’ll be mostly if not fully dry within about an hour. This is probably the best drying method available to you if you’re short on time. As you did while washing, be careful not to overfill the dryer. Friction equals fraying. If you want to be extra delicate with your linen, kill the heat altogether and let gravity do the work.Tip: If you’re not planning on using your sheets right away, fold them and put them up as soon as they come out of the dryer to keep them from developing wrinkles.

steps.headline: Allow your sheets to air dry if you want to extend their lifespan.
steps.description: Simply stretch your still-damp sheets out on a clothesline or drying rack and leave them there until all of the moisture has evaporated out of them. To speed things along a bit, switch on the air conditioning or an overhead fan, or place a portable box fan nearby to increase the amount of airflow that your bedding gets. All in all, your sheets should be dry and ready to go back on the bed within about 3-4 hours. If you want to air out your linen but don’t have a clothesline or drying rack, you can also try hanging them over the railing of your porch or balcony, or draping them over the backs of a couple chairs situated close together.

steps.headline: Iron your sheets on low heat to ease out wrinkles.
steps.description: The relaxed, lived-in look of linen is yet another of its many charms, which means that ironing isn't generally required. If you have some serious wrinkles or creases to work out, however, do it with a warm (not hot!) iron while your sheets are still slightly damp to decrease your chances of doing heat-related damage. Never use a hot iron on dry linen sheets, as this could easily ruin the fabric by causing burns or discoloration. Some experts also recommend putting the sheets back on your bed before they’re fully dry. Stretching them taut will make them dry nice and smooth.
